title: Time Machine Session: Introduction

author: Martha Larson, Department of Mediamatics, Delft University of Technology (TU Delft)

segmentation: Hello everybody and welcome to the ice and I see me 2012 time machine session.
Today we're going to turn back the Clock.
And we're going to have a look at the past of multimedia technology and multimedia research.
For the long standing members of the community here, this will be maybe like a trip down memory Lane.
And and for the the newer members of the research community.
It will be a strong sensation astronomy sensation of time work.
So in my brief introduction today, I want to tell you about what to expect during the next 2 hours.
Um, The Time Machine session is an innovation.
Of ice candy.
Uh.

It is how the first time for this year and Magento car and I would like to thank the general Chairs by Simi 2012 and organizing committee for their incredible support and their efforts to make this very innovative session happen.
So what do you expect today?
Well, as you heard in the opening yesterday, The Time Machine session is dedicated to topics that are centered on ideas that were published before their time and were never fully exploited.
But we're not just talking about old ideas today.
Instead, a time machine topic is a topic that is currently experiencing renewed relevance as a result of developments both in technology and developments in expectations and needs of us as users.
The session consists of talks on four topics.
He talks about proposed by experts in the field, the talks we presented in 20 minutes, and they will be followed by questions.
So first of all, we'll have Charlie Angueira will be telling us about dynamic time warping, then John Brown talking about com technology.
Then we'll harvest of the money.
Who will tell us about effective multimedia analysis and finally went in saying higher order entropy coding.
So what are the goals of this session?
What are we trying to achieve?
We want to stimulate ourselves to look, to observe, to talk to each other, to listen to each other.
Our experts will not shy away from controversy during this session, so please be thinking about your questions as you listen to them talk.
Another goal is to emphasize the benefits of knowing the literature.

NOI and reading the literature, the related work sections of our papers are important sections, and we want to remind ourselves that is worth the time and the effort that we devote to exploring the work is done in the past.
We all want to avoid reinventing the wheel.
Taking a deep and very conscious look at the past will help us to streamline innovation and reduce redundancy.
However, there's a certain kind of redundancy that we cherish as a research community, and this is the redundancy that happens when we.
Repeat car results when we.
Re implement things that people have done before.
For example, you take a baseline from the state of the art previous paper and use that to compare it against your new approach.
And finally, our final goal.
We believe that really knowing where the field has been will stimulate creative new algorithms.
In particular, it will allow us to more effectively recognize innovation when we encounter it and more quickly understand the potential of our own ideas.
So I invite you to sit back, enjoy the rest of this trip into history as we spend some time now allowing the past to speak to us.
Starting from this specific time machine topics today, we hope that this session opens the wider question of what can we just re discover in our?
Field.
And here is the key.
That rediscovery will feed and enrich our future work.
The feeling of time war arises because by looking back we are in fact looking forward.
